PT J
AN ZOOR15103017466
DT Article
TI Archaeoovulus palenae, n. gn., n. sp. (Icnofossilia): a fossil
   amphibious ootheca from the pre-evaporitic Messinian site of Capo di
   Fiume, Palena (Abruzzo).
FT Archaeoovulus palenae, n. gn., n. sp. (icnofossilia): ooteca fossile di
   anfibio del messiniano pre-evaporitico di Capo di Fiume, presso Palena
   (abruzzo).
AU Capasso, Luigi Lorenzo
   Pallizzi, Attanasio
   Milia, Luisa
   D'Anastasio, Ruggero (r.danastasio@unich.it) 
SO Atti della Societa Toscana di Scienze Naturali Residente in Pisa Memorie
   Serie A
VL 120
PS 25-38
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Authors describe a Messinian icnofossil of an ootheca, coming from
   the paleontological site of Palena. Its morphological and dimensional
   characteristics do not match with the oothecae of modern Teleostei
   correlated with the fossil fishes from the same paleontological site.
   Therefore, the Authors compared this fossil ootheca with the ones of
   extant amphibians, and evidenced similarities with Bufo viridis ootheca.
   The fossil from Palena is significantly different from other known
   fossil oothecae, and its uniqueness justifies the creation of a new
   taxon. The discovery of this fossil, together with Palena tanatocenosis,
   confirms that the ancient Messinian basin was characterized by a wide
   range of salinity, compatible with survival and reproduction of both
   marine and fresh water vertebrates such as the amphibians of the genus
   Bufo.
C1 D'Anastasio, Ruggero; Univ G DAnnunzio, Museo Univ, Piazza Trento &
   Trieste 1, Chieti, I-66100, Italy, Italy.
EM r.danastasio@unich.it
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0365-7655
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Neogene
DE Archaeoovulus [Egg / New genus, Miocene / ] [Miocene /  / New genus
   described from fossil egg; Possibly attributable to Bufo viridis
   (Amphibia)]. 
   Archaeoovulus palenae [Italy /  / new species; Described from fossil
   egg] [Miocene /  / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Archaeoovulus (Animalia): [Gen nov, Type species Archaeoovulus palenae,
   p. 28, Miocene, Described from fossil egg possibly attributable to Bufo
   viridis (Amphibia); Fossil]. 
   Archaeoovulus palenae (Animalia): [Sp nov, Italy, Miocene, P. 28,
   Described from fossil egg; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15208048885
DT Article
TI Sinharaja gen. n., a new Uropodina mite genus from Sri Lanka with
   description of two new species (Acari: Mesostigmata: Uropodidae).
AU Kontschan, Jeno (kontschan.jeno@agrar.mta.hu) 
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 68
IS 1
PS 150-154
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new Uropodina genus (Sinharaja gen. n.) is described on the basis of
   two new species (S. ceylonensis sp. n. and S. sinhala sp. n.) from Sri
   Lanka. The new genus differs by the strongly sclerotised dorsal lines,
   pentagonal pygidial shield, the shape and length of dorsal setae and the
   shape of first and fourth hypstomal setae, internal malae and epistome
   from the other known Uropodina genera.
C1 Kontschan, Jeno; Hungarian Acad Sci, Inst Plant Protect, POB 102,
   Budapest, H-1525, Hungary, Hungary.
EM kontschan.jeno@agrar.mta.hu
RI Kontschan, Jeno/G-6807-2012
SC Zoology
SN 0006-3088
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Sinharaja ceylonensis; Sinharaja sinhala [Sri Lanka /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Sinharaja (Acari): [Gen nov, Of family Uropodidae, Type species
   Sinharaja ceylonensis, p. 150]. 
   Sinharaja ceylonensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Sri Lanka, P. 151]. 
   Sinharaja sinhala (Acari): [Sp nov, Sri Lanka, P. 153]. 
   Trigonuropoda - Traegardh 1952 (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, P. 151].

DT Article
TI SPECIES OF THE GENUS MACROPOSTHONIA AND CRICONEMOIDES (NEMATODA:
   TYLENCHIDAE): ASSOCIATED WITH MULBERRY PLANTS WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW
   SPECIES FROM MANIPUR, INDIA.
AU Bina, Loukrakpam (bina.chanu@gmail.com) 
   Mohilal, Naorem
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 233-242
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During a survey for soil and plant parasitic nematodes, seven known
   species and a new species of nematode of the subfamily Macroposthoniinae
   (Criconematidae) from different localities of Manipur, India associated
   with mulberry plants were found. All the species are illustrated with
   line diagrams and described here with their morphometric data presented
   in five tables, along with localities and host plants.
C1 Bina, Loukrakpam; Manipur Univ, Parasitol Sect, Canchipur, Manipur,
   795003, India, India.

DT Article
TI ONE NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS HIRSCHMANNIELLA LUC AND GOODEY, 1963 AND
   NEW HOST RECORD FROM MANIPUR, INDIA.
AU Gyaneswori, I. (iromgyaneswari@yahoo.com) 
   Gambhir, R.K.
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 261-262
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During a survey of nematodes associated with citrus plants in Manipur,
   revealed the presence of one new species of the genus Hirschmanniella
   Luc and Goodey, 1963. The new species was recovered from the soil around
   the Citrus maxima (Lemon) plant, which is a new host record.
   Hirschmanniella is distinguished by having longer stylet, oesophagus and
   longer tail length with a single mucro in both male and female species.
C1 Gyaneswori, I.; Krishi Vigyan Kendra, FEEDS Hengbung, Hengbung, Manipur,
   795129, India, India.
EM iromgyaneswari@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Hirschmanniella [Plant hosts / Citrus maxima / New record] [Manipur /  /
   ]. 
   Hirschmanniella citruini [Plant hosts / Citrus maxima / New parasite
   species] [Manipur /  / New species from plant host]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Hirschmanniella (Nematoda): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Hirschmanniella citruini (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Manipur, Parasite of
   Citrus maxima (Plant), p. 261; Parasite].

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF NEW SPECIES OF KLEIDOTOMA WESTWOOD (HYMENOPTERA:
   FIGITIDAE) FROM INDIA ALONG WITH A LIST OF SPECIES.
AU Akhtar, Mir Samim
   Singh, Longjam Roni Kumar
   Ramamurthy, V.V. (vvrento@gmail.com) 
   Khan, Farmanur Rahman
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 315-320
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Kleidotoma is reported for the first time from India with
   Kleidotoma sikkimensis sp. nov. Akhtar. The new species is described
   from Sikkim, India and distinguished from K. kraussi Yoshimoto through
   malar space about 0.32x height of eye, scape 1.66x as long as broad,
   pronotum behind plate on each side with about 2 costate extending
   somewhat diagonal to margin of mesoscutum, radial cell moderate in size,
   apical portion of radial vein not extending beyond radial cell along the
   wing margin, scutellar cup not extending to the apex of the disc. A list
   of Kleidotoma is given which includes 119 species, of this 74 species
   from Palearctic, 16 species from Afrotropical, 4 species from Neotropic,
   2 species from Oriental, 1 species each from Antarctic and Australasian,
   18 species from Nearctic + Neotropic, 1 species each from Palearctic +
   Australasian and Palearctic + Neotropic and 1 species from Neotropic +
   Australasian + Nearctic region along with synonyms and distributions.
C1 Ramamurthy, V.V.; Indian Agr Res Inst, Div Entomol, New Delhi, 110012,
   India, India.
EM vvrento@gmail.com
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Kleidotoma [Checklists / Distributional & taxonomic checklist / ] [India
   /  / New record]. 
   Kleidotoma sikkimensis [Sikkim /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Kleidotoma - Westwood 1833 (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Kleidotoma sikkimensis - Akhtar 2013 (Cynipidae): [Sp nov, Sikkim, Host
   unknown, p. 316]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15102007708
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF AIOLOPUS FIEBER (ACRIDIDAE: OEDIPODINAE) FROM RANCHI
   (JHARKHAND).
AU Siddiqui, Sumbul (info@alamhospital.in) 
   Shamim, S.M.
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 321-323
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Aiolopus Fieber, 1853 is represented by three species A.
   simulatrix (Walker), A. tamulus (Fabricius) and A. thalassinus
   (Fabricius) from India. During the course of the survey of Jharkhand
   apart from some old described species, a new species viz. A. ranchiensis
   sp. n. have been found which has been described with six illustrations
   and a revised key to accommodate the new species is also provided.
C1 Siddiqui, Sumbul; Ranchi Univ, Dept Zool, Ranchi, Bihar, 834008, India,
   India.
EM info@alamhospital.in
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Aiolopus [India /  / Key to species].

   include new species, p. 322]. 
   Aiolopus ranchiensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Jharkhand, P. 323].

DT Article
TI A NEW ERIOPHYID MITE (ACARI: PROSTIGMATA) FROM INDIA.
AU Joshi, Sushila
   Menon, Pratibha (pratibharish@gmail.com) 
   Ramamurthy, V.V.
SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 339-342
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of eriophyid (Acari: Prostigmata) viz. Aceria amrini n.
   sp., was collected from Tamarix aphylla (Tamaraceae), from India. The
   distinguishing characters are 6 rayed empodium, prodorsal shield clear
   with no lines or granules, dorsal annuli without microtubercles,
   microtubercles present only on the last few annuli ventrally, antapical
   seta and accessory seta present. The paper includes a key to Aceria spp.
   reported from Tamarix spp. and a checklist of all eriophyid species
   known on Tamarix spp. with details on their synonyms, type host, damage
   symptoms and type locality.
C1 Menon, Pratibha; Indian Agr Res Inst, Div Entomol, New Delhi, 110012,
   India, India.
EM pratibharish@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Aceria [Plant hosts / Tamarix / Key to parasite species]. 
   Aceria amrini [Plant hosts / Tamarix aphylla / New parasite species]
   [Delhi /  / New species from plant host]. 
   Eriophyidae [Checklists / Distributional checklist / ] [Plant hosts /
   Tamarix / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Aceria - Keifer 1944 (Acari): [Key to species, Parasites of Tamarix
   (Plant), p. 340; Parasite]. 
   Aceria amrini - Joshi 2013 (Acari): [Sp nov, Delhi, Parasite of Tamarix
   aphylla (Plant), p. 339; Parasite]. 
   Eriophyidae (Acari): [Parasite].

AN ZOOR15102007712

   (ALEYRODIDAE: HEMIPTERA) FROM INDIA.
AU Phillips, Annie (anniep817@gmail.com)

SO Bioscan
VL 8
IS 1
SU S
PS 343-347
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A study on the systematics of whiteflies from the campus of Madras
   Christian College, Tambaram, Tamil Nadu, India was conducted between
   August 1999 and December 2002. From the study two new species of
   whiteflies have been determined - one species named Dialeurodes
   megaspina and the other assigned to a new genus Milleraleurodes with a
   new species illuminata. Dialeurodes radiipuncta (Quaintance and Baker)
   and Dialeuropora murrayae (Takahashi) are reported for the first time
   from India.
C1 Phillips, Annie; Stella Maris Coll, Dept Zool, Madras, Tamil Nadu,
   600086, India, India.
EM anniep817@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Dialeurodes megaspina [Plant hosts / Tarenna asiatica / New parasite
   species] [Tamil Nadu /  / New species from plant host]. 
   Dialeurodes radiipuncta [Plant hosts / Memecylon edule / Systematics] [
   / Memecylon umbellatum / New record] [India /  / ] [Tamil Nadu /
   Tambaram / ]. 
   Dialeuropora murrayae [Plant hosts / Glycosmis mauritiana / New record;
   systematics] [India /  / ] [Tamil Nadu / Tambaram / ]. 
   Milleraleurodes illuminata [Plant hosts / Glycosmis mauritiana / New
   parasite species] [ / Santalum album / ] [Tamil Nadu /  / New species
   from plant host].

TI A NEW BUTTERFLY SPECIES FROM THE COLOMBIAN ANDES (LEPIDOPTERA:
   NYMPHALIDAE: SATYRINAE).
FT NUEVA ESPECIE DE MARIPOSA (LEPIDOPTERA: NYMPHALIDAE: SATYRINAE) PARA LOS
   ANDES COLO MBIANOS.
AU Villalobos Moreno, Alfonso (alfvillalmo@gmail.com) 
SO Boletin Cientifico Museo de Historia Natural Universidad de Caldas
VL 17
IS 1
PS 268-275
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Idioneurula Strand 1932 is described from
   high elevation habitats (paramos) of Santurban, Santander Department, in
   the eastern Andes of Colombia. Based on adult morphology, we propose
   treating Idioneurula as comprising five species: I. erebioides (C.
   Felder & R. Felder, 1867); I. donegani Huertas & Arias, 2007; I. eremita
   Viloria & Pyrcz, 2007; I. jacquelinae (Pyrcz, 1995) and I. socorroi
   Villalobos-Moreno & Salazar n. sp.
C1 Villalobos Moreno, Alfonso; Univ Nacl Colombia, Calle 9 Carrera
   27,Edificio Camilo Torres,Campus, Santander, Spain, Spain.
EM alfvillalmo@gmail.com

DT Article
TI First record of the jellyfish of the genus Lychnorhiza (Cnidaria:
   Scyphozoa: Rhizostomeae: Lychnorhizidae) in the Colombian Caribbean.
FT Primer registro de medusas del genero Lychnorhiza (Cnidaria: Scyphozoa:
   Rhizostomeae: Lychnorhizidae) en el mar caribe colombiano.
AU Maria Cedeno-Posso, Cristina (proyecto.medusozoa.colombia@gmail.com) 
   Lecompte Perez, Orlando Pedro
SO Boletin de Investigaciones Marinas y Costeras
VL 42
IS 2
PS 387-393
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB This paper reports for the first time in Colombia the jellyfish
   Lychnorhiza sp., aff. L. lucerna, based on seventeen individuals
   collected in front of Isla de Rosario (Magdalena). This jellyfish is one
   of the most common inhabitants in coastal waters from southeastern
   Brazil to northern Argentina, but it was not recorded yet from the
   Caribbean coast of Colombia.
C1 Maria Cedeno-Posso, Cristina; Univ Bogota Jorge Tadeo Lozano Sede Santa
   Marta, Fac Ciencias Nat & Ingn, Carrera 2 11-68,Edificio Mundo Marino,

DT Article
TI Two new Palaearctic species of Uroleucon (Hemiptera: Aphididae) from the
   collection of the Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle de Paris.
AU Nieto Nafria, Juan M. (jmnien@unileon.es) 
   Perez Hidalgo, Nicolas
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 37
IS 1-2
PS 1-17
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new Palaearctic species of Uroleucon Mordvilko (Hemiptera:
   Aphididae: Aphidinae Macrosiphini) are described. Uroleucon (Uroleucon)
   teheranense n. sp. is described from apterous viviparous females caught
   on Lapsana sp. near Tehran (Iran) and Uroleucon (Uromelan) ariegense n.
   sp. is described from both apterous and alate viviparae caught on
   Campanula sp. in southern France. U. teheranense is compared with the
   few species belonging to subgenus Uroleucon that present 3 setae on
   first segment of tarsi, and with the species included in the key to
   apterae on Lapsana by BLACKMAN & EASTOP (2006), which is modified. U.
   ariegense is compared with the species of Uroleucon living on
   Campanulaceae species, mainly with the species included in BLACKMAN &
   EASTOP's key to apterae on Campanula, which is modified.
C1 Nieto Nafria, Juan M.; Univ Leon, Dept Biodiversidad & Gest Ambiental,
   Leon, E-24071, Spain, Spain.
EM jmnien@unileon.es
SC Zoology
SN 0210-8984
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe
DE Uroleucon ariegense [France /  / New species]. 
   Uroleucon teheranense [Iran /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,

   subordinate taxa, Palaearctic species, p. 10].

   Uroleucon teheranense (Aphidoidea): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 3].

TI The genus Hermannia in the Iberian Peninsula. First record of H.
   (Phyllhermannia) for the Western Palaearctic subregion and description
   of H. (Ph.) longisetosa n. sp. (Acari, Oribatida, Hermanniidae).
FT El genero Hermannia en la peninsula iberica. Primera cita paleartica
   occidental de H. (Phyllhermannia) y descripcion de H. (Ph.) longisetosa
   n. sp. (Acari, Oribatida, Hermanniidae).
AU Subias, Luis S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya.
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 37
IS 1-2
PS 1-6
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the genus Hermannia Nicolet, 1855 in the Iberian
   Peninsula, and the tropical subgenus Hermannia (Phyllhermannia) Berlese,
   1916. This subgenus is recorded for the first time for the Palaearctic
   subregion. A new species, Hermannia (Phyllhermannia) longisetosa n. sp.,
   is described, and the boreal species Hermannia (Heterohermannia)
   reticulata Thorell, 1871 is recorded in the Iberian Peninsula for the
   first time.
C1 Subias, Luis S.; Univ Complutense, Fac Biol, Madrid, E-28040, Spain,
   Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR15307045666
DT Article
TI A key of the Charipinae (Hymenoptera, Cynipoidea, Figitidae) from Spain,
   including new records and species.
AU Ferrer-Suay, Mar (mar.ferrer.suay@gmail.com) 
   Selfa, Jesus
   Ribes, Antoni
   Pujade-Villar, Juli
SO Boletin de la Asociacion Espanola de Entomologia
VL 37
IS 3-4
PS 315-341
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Charipinae material from Spain has been studied. Two new species are
   described: Alloxysta viellae Ferrer-Suay & Pujade-Villar n. sp. and
   Phaenoglyphis montoliui Ferrer-Suay & Pujade-Villar n. sp. Their
   morphological features and diagnostic characters are discussed and
   illustrated. Five Alloxysta species are recorded for the first time from
   Spain: Alloxysta darci (Girault, 1933), Alloxysta fracticornis (Thomson,
   1862), Alloxysta mullensis (Cameron, 1883), Alloxysta pilipennis
   (Hartig, 1840) and Alloxysta ramulifera (Thomson, 1862). The two Spanish
   species, described from Tenerife by Kieffer (1904), are here synonymized
   with different valid species: Alloxysta afra (Kieffer, 1904) is a new
   synonymy of Alloxysta consobrina (Zetterstedt, 1838); the paralectotype
   corresponds to Phaenoglyphis villosa (Hartig, 1841); Alloxysta cabrerai
   (Kieffer, 1904) is a new synonymy of Alloxysta macrophadna (Hartig,
   1841); the paralectotype corresponds to Alloxysta castanea (Hartig,
   1841). A key for all the Charipinae species present in Spain is given.
C1 Ferrer-Suay, Mar; Univ Barcelona, Fac Biol, Avda Diagonal 645,
   Barcelona, E-08028, Spain, Spain.
EM mar.ferrer.suay@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0210-8984
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Alloxysta darci; Alloxysta fracticornis; Alloxysta mullensis; Alloxysta
   pilipennis; Alloxysta ramulifera [Spain /  / New record]. 
   Alloxysta viellae; Phaenoglyphis montoliui [Spain /  / New species]. 
   Charipinae [Spain /  / Key to species] [ /  / Faunal list; new record;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae
OR Alloxysta comsobrina - (Zetterstedt 1838) (Cynipidae): [Syn nov,
   Alloxysta afra (Kieffer 1904), p. 322]. 
   Alloxysta darci (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Alloxysta fracticornis (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Alloxysta macrophadna - (Hartig 1841) (Cynipidae): [Syn nov, Alloxysta
   cabrerai (Kieffer 1904), p. 323]. 
   Alloxysta mullensis (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Alloxysta pilipennis (Cynipidae): [New record]. 
   Alloxysta ramulifera (Cynipidae): [New record].

   [Sp nov, Spain, P. 331].

DT Article
TI List of species, biological data and illustrated key to the
   identification of mosquito larvae (Diptera: Culicidae) found in
   artificial breeding in Uruguay.
FT Lista de especies y clave ilustrada para la identificacion de larvas de
   mosquitos (diptera: Culicidae) halladas criando en recipientes
   artificiales en Uruguay.
AU Rossi, Gustavo C. (mm@fcien.edu.uy) 
   Martinez, Maria
SO Boletin de la Sociedad Zoologica del Uruguay Segunda Epoca
VL 22
IS 2
PS 49-65
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present the list of species and an illustrated key to the recognition
   of genera and species of mosquito larvae of fourth instar were found
   breeding in artificial containers and other artificial environments as
   household drains in Uruguay. The country is known to occur in 12 genera
   and 51 species of mosquitoes, 22 species, spread over six genera, were
   found breeding in artificial environments (including 18 in the key):
   Aedes aegypti (Linnaeus), Aedes albopictus Skuse, Anopheles
   (Nyssorhynchus) sp., Anopheles (Anopheles) sp., Culex apicinus Philippi,
   Culex coronator Dyar & Knab, Culex dolosus (Lynch Arribalzaga), Culex
   maxi Dyar, Culex mollis Dyar & Knab, Culex quinquefasciatus Say, Culex
   pipiens (L.), Culex saltanensis Dyar, Ochlerotatus albifasciatus
   (Maquart), Ochlerotatus crinifer (Theobald), Ochlerotatus fluviatilis
   (Lutz), Ochlerotatus scapularis (Rondani), Psorophora ciliata
   (Fabricius), Psorophora cingulata (Fabricius), Psorophora confinnis
   (Lynch A.), Psorophora (Grabhamia) sp., Psorophora (Janthinosoma) sp.
   and Toxorhynchites (Lynchiella) theobaldi (Dyar & Knab). Culex apicinus,
   Cx. mollis and Psorophora cingulata are recorded for the first time in
   Uruguay.
C1 Rossi, Gustavo C.; Univ Nacl La Plata, CEPAVE, Calle 2 584,B1902CHX, La
   Plata, Argentina, Argentina.
EM mm@fcien.edu.uy

   Habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

   record].

   faunal list] [Uruguay /  / Key to species] [ /  / ].

DT Article
TI Revision of the Taxonomical Status of Liolaemus donosoi Ortiz, 1975
   (Iguania: Liolaemidae).
FT Revision del estatus taxonomic de Liolaemus donosoi Ortiz, 1975
   (iguania: Liolaemidae).
AU Troncoso-Palacios, Jaime (jtroncosopalacios@gmail.com) 
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 62
PS 119-127
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Liolaemus donosoi Ortiz, 1975, is a species with a complex taxonomic
   history. The original description lacks comparisons with related species
   and further works have proposed that it is a) indistinguishable from L.
   constanzae. b) it is a subspecies of it, or c) it is a full species.
   Herein 1 review the taxonomic history and morphological characteristics
   of L. donosoi, and concluded that it is a junior synonym of L.
   constanzae.
C1 Troncoso-Palacios, Jaime; Univ Chile, Fac Med, Casilla 70005, Santiago,
   Chile, Chile.
EM jtroncosopalacios@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0027-3910
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America

   / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Sauria, Iguanidae

TI Geosphaeropterus, new genus of Tropiphorini (Coleoptera: Curculionidae)
   from Chile, description of three new species.
FT Geosphaeropterus, nuevo genero de Tropiphorini (coleoptera:
   Curculionidae) de Chile, con descripcion de tres nuevas especies.
AU Elgueta, Mario (melgueta@mnhn.cl) 
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 62
PS 203-217
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and three new species are described. The new species inhabit
   coastal and continental sand dunes in the north of Chile. The new
   species are related with some Strangaliodes representatives, but
   differences in some internal and external characters justify its
   position in a new genus.

DT Article
TI A NEW COLEOPTEROUS SPECIES FROM MINORCA, POTOSIA CUPREA (FABRICIUS,
   1775) AND DESCRIPTION OF FERRERIESENSIS NOV SSP (SCARABAEIDAE,
   CETONIIDAE).
FT Una nueva especie de coleoptero para Menorca, Potosia cuprea (Fabricius,
   1775) y descripcion de Potosia cuprea ferreriesensis nov. ssp.
   (Scarabaeidae, Cetoniinae).
AU Compte-Sart, Arturo
   Angel Carreras-Torrent, Miguel
SO Bolleti de la Societat d'Historia Natural de les Balears
VL 56
PS 59-72
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Potosia cuprea (Fabr., 1775) is recorded from Minorca, and all Balearic
   islands, for the first time. It is also described as ferreriesensis nov.
   ssp. For their abundance and apparent localization near Ferreries it is
   a surprising find. The compared study of all euroafrican subspecies
   shows that the Iberian one is the nearest, but the Minorca race is
   different by the bigger size, greater green reflection, conspicuous
   elitral and ventral spots, corporal structure, joined to their
   insularity.
C1 Compte-Sart, Arturo; CSIC, Museo Nacl Ciencias Nat, Jose Gutierrez
   Abascal 2, Madrid, E-28006, Spain, Spain.
SC Zoology
SN 0212-260X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Spain

   Potosia cuprea ferreriesensis [Balearic Islands /  / New subspecies].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203018577
DT Article
TI The water mites (Hydrachnidia and Halacaridae) of the collection Daniele
   Benfatti at the Museo Civico di Storia Naturale Verona.
AU Gerecke, Reinhard
   Di Sabatino, Antonio
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 37
PS 67-111
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The DANIELE BENFAT TI collection of water mites (Hydrachnidia and
   Halacaridae) deposited and curated at the Museo Civico di Storia
   Naturale di Verona is the largest public collection of this group of
   freshwater invertebrates in Italy. It includes over 10.000 specimens
   collected by BENFATTI (1100 slide-mounted, the remaining in KOENIKE's
   fluid), representing 166 species out of 57 genera and 26 families. Due
   to the addition of 431 specimens, mostly ex coll. GERECKE, including 160
   species, 84 of which not represented in coll. BENFATTI, the total
   species number amounts to 246. Geographical focus areas are the Italian
   Alps (regions of Trentino and Piemonte), the lowlands surrounding
   Mantova and Verona (Venezia tridentina), the Northern Apennines (Regions
   Emilia Romagna, Liguria and Toscana) and the French Island of Corsica.
   This paper includes: (1) a list of the material; (2) the discussion of
   remarkable taxonomic details, including descriptions of seven species
   new to science: Atractides giustinii, A. ruffoi and Aturus scapulatus
   (Corsica), Axonopsis danielei (Corsica and Liguria), Hygrobates
   psammocrenicus (peninsular Italy and Corsica), H. helocrenicus
   (peninsular Italy and Sicily) and Torrenticola tyrrhenica (Sicily,
   Corsica); (3) a discussion of zoogeographically interesting new records
   (17 species recorded for the first time from Italy, 14 from Corsica,
   regional faunal lists enriched by 48 species for Emilia Romagna, 18 for
   Liguria, 7 for Toscana, 5 for Veneto, and 2 for Lombardia).
C1 Gerecke, Reinhard; Biesingerstr 11, Tubingen, DE-72070, Germany,
   Germany.
SC Zoology; Education &Educational Research
SN 1590-8399
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Animals and man; Education and

PT J
AN ZOOR15203018578
DT Article
TI Two new subgenera and two new species of Pterostichus from China
   (Coleoptera Carabidae).
AU Sciaky, Riccardo (riccardo.sciaky1@tin.it) 
   Allegro, Gianni
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 37
PS 113-122
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new subgenera of Pterostichus are here described. Orientostichus n.
   subg. contains several species already known from China and neighbouring
   countries and an additional one, Pterostichus (Orientostichus) pulcher
   n. sp., from Southern Sichuan, herewith described. P. pratti (Bates,
   1890), of which is here fixed the lectotype upon a specimen from Washan,
   is here designated as the type-species of the subgenus Orientostichus.
   The diagnostic combination of characters of this subgenus is:
   integuments deep black, body and appendages stout, epipleurae "crossed",
   mesocoxae with only two setae, mesofemora with no additional setae, last
   sternite of male often with particular formations (carinae, pits, etc.),
   aedeagus with very short basal portion and long and twisted apex.
   Pterostichus (Orientostichus) pulcher n. sp. is mainly characterized by
   the catenulate elytral sculpture, which is, as far as it is known until
   now, unique within the subgenus. The second subgenus, Tubuliphallus n.
   subg., contains only P. (Tubuliphallus) megacephalus n. sp. from
   Sichuan, herewith described. It is mainly characterised by the peculiar
   shape of the male genitalia. The diagnostic combination of characters of
   Tubuliphallus n. subg. is: integuments deep black, body and appendages
   stout, epipleurae very shortly "crossed", mesocoxae with only two setae,
   mesofemora with no additional setae, last sternite of male simple;
   aedeagus long and slender, with a short prebasal portion joining at
   almost right angle the median lobe, which is cylindrical, apically
   truncate and provided with a small preapical ostium. It is not possible,
   at the present status of knowledge, to place this subgenus near any
   other of the many subgenera of Pterostichus known from China. The single
   species here included, P. (Tubuliphallus) megacephalus n. sp., has eyes
   slightly reduced, tumid tempora and tarsi particularly thick in lateral
   view. A short discussion on the different types of irregularity in the
   elytral sculpture within the genus Pterostichus is also provided, with
   several illustrations showing some instances.
C1 Sciaky, Riccardo; Milano CRA PLF, Milan, Italy, Italy.
EM riccardo.sciaky1@tin.it
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8399
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Pterostichus (Orientostichus) pulcher; Pterostichus (Tubuliphallus)
   megacephalus [Sichuan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Pterostichus (Orientostichus) (Carabidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Pterostichus pratti Bates 1890, p. 114]. 
   Pterostichus (Orientostichus) pulcher (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan, P.
   115]. 
   Pterostichus (Tubuliphallus) (Carabidae): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Pterostichus (Tubuliphallus) megacephalus, p. 118]. 
   Pterostichus (Tubuliphallus) megacephalus (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Sichuan,
   P. 119]. 
   Pterostichus pratti - Bates 1890 (Carabidae): [Designated type species
   for new subgenus, Pterostichus (Orientostichus), p. 114; Lectotype
   designated, P. 115].

PT J
AN ZOOR15203018001
DT Article
TI A new genus and species, Slovenitriacanthus saksidai, from southwestern
   Slovenia, of the Upper Cretaceous basal tetraodontiform fish family
   Cretatriacanthidae (Plectocretacicoidea).
AU Tyler, James C. (tylerj@si.edu) 
   Kriznar, Matija
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 37
PS 45-55
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A 15.9 mm SL specimen from the Lipica Formation of Upper Santonian-Lower
   Campanian age (about 82-84 MYA) at Sepulje, near Tomaj, about 14 km
   southeast of Komen, in southwestern Slovenia, is described as
   Slovenitriacanthus saksidai, new genus and species. It is the second
   known taxon of the Upper Cretaceous basal tetraodontiform fish family
   Cretatriacanthidae, which was previously represented only by the
   holotype of Cretatriacanthus guidottii Tyler and Sorbini 1996 from the
   Upper Campanian-Lower Maastrichtian of Nardo (Puglia), southeastern
   Italy (about 70 MYA). The diminutive size of Slovenitriacanthus saksidai
   and its well-ossified and presumably adult body are similar to those of
   all of the other known specimens of the three Upper Cretaceous families
   that comprise the superfamily Plectocretacicoidea, supporting the
   proposal that a reduced size of 25 mm SL or less is a synapomorphy of
   the superfamily.
C1 Tyler, James C.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, MRC 159,POB
   37012, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM tylerj@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8402
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Slovenitriacanthus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Slovenitriacanthus saksidai [Slovenia /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  /
   ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Tetraodontiformes, Cretatriacanthidae
OR Cretatriacanthidae (Tetraodontiformes): [Emended diagnosis, P. 51]. 
   Slovenitriacanthus (Cretatriacanthidae): [Gen nov, Type species
   Slovenitriacanthus saksidai, p. 46, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Slovenitriacanthus saksidai (Cretatriacanthidae): [Sp nov, Slovenia,
   Cretaceous, P. 47; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Notes on Boldoriella of the carminatii species group: Boldoriella
   silvanae stat. nov. and taxonomy of related species. (Coleoptera
   Carabidae Trechinae).
FT Note su Boldoriella del gruppo carminatii: Boldoriella silvanae stat.
   nov. e osservazioni sistematiche suite specie affini (Coleoptera
   Carabidae Trechinae).
AU Monzini, V. (vittorino.monzini@fastwebnet.it) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 145
IS 1
PS 3-8
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this contribution, the taxonomic status of Boldoriella carminatii
   silvanae Monzini, 1995, is changed to Boldoriella silvanae, stat. nov.
   Many populations of Boldoriella carminatii (sensu lato) are reviewed to,
   as well as two closely related species: Boldoriella manzoniana Monzini,
   1995, and Boldoriella concii Monguzzi, 1982 (sensu lato). These four
   species, because of their morphological affinities and distribution
   nearness, seem to form a single monophyletic lineage. For that reason,
   they are here aggregated into a carminatii species group of the genus
   Boldoriella.
C1 Monzini, V.; Via M Polo 3, San Giuliano Milanese, MI, 20098, USA, USA.
EM vittorino.monzini@fastwebnet.it
SC Zoology
SN 0373-3491

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Carabidae
OR Boldoriella carminatii silvanae - Monzini 1995 (Carabidae): [Raised to,
   Boldoriella silvanae, p. 4]. 
   Boldoriella carminatii species group (Carabidae): [Key to species, P.
   4]. 
   Boldoriella silvanae - Monzini 1995 (Carabidae): [Raised from,

AN ZOOR15111069502
DT Article
TI Three new species of subterranean beetles of Greece (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae and Cholevidae).
FT Tre nuove specie di Coleotteri sotterranei di Grecia (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae e Cholevidae).
AU Casale, A. (a_casale@libero.it) 
   Giachino, P.M.
   Vailati, D.
SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 145
IS 1
PS 9-25
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A synthesis is presented of the arthropod fauna known so far from the
   Megalo Spilio (= big cave), located in Oros Serekas Mt. (Western Greece,
   Etholia-Akarnania). Three new species of subterranean beetles are
   described and illustrated from this cave. Duvalius (Duvalius) ionicus
   Casale, Giachino & Vailati, new species (Carabidae, Trechini), sympatric
   and syntopic with the congeneric species Duvalius (Euduvalius) ruffoanus
   Casale, Giachino, Vailati & Vigna Taglianti, 1996 is readily
   distinguished by the peculiar combination of morphological features in
   the elytral chaetotaxy, shape of the basal fore tarsomers in the Male,
   and the unique structure of the median lobe of aedeagus, endophallus and
   copulatory piece. Therefore, this new taxon cannot be attributed to any
   Duvalius species group proposed so far for the Greek species of this
   genus. Speluncarius vailatii Casale & Giachino, new species (Carabidae,
   Pterostichini), is probably close to S. henroti Cerruti, 1973, known so
   far from the female holotype from the Drogarati cave in Cephalonia
   island. From the latter it is recognized by the smaller size (14.5 mm in
   S. henroti), the full atrophy of eyes, the narrower, elongate pronotum
   with anterolateral angles acutely prominent, the elytral intervals
   convex, and the presence of two only discal pores on the third elytral
   interval, adjacent to the second stria (the anterior one is absent,
   although it is present in S. henroti). Epiroella acharnanis Giachino,
   Vailati & Casale, new species (Cholevidae, Leptodirinae), is attributed
   to the genus Epiroella Casale, Giachino, Vailati & Rampini, 1991 (status
   novus, valid genus), and is recognized from E. muelleriana (Paoletti,
   1975) and E. epirota (Giachino, 1989) by the smaller size, the elytral
   surface with transversal striation slightly evident, the more prominent
   mesostemal keel, the reduced size of aedeagus, and the different shape
   of the structures in endophallus and spennatheca. Some data are also
   provided on the faunal origin and composition of the area. The extant
   taxa show a complex composition of the fauna as the result of
   overlapping of "North-Aegean lineages" through the Pyndos chain, later
   connections with the Cephalonia island during the Messinian
   Mediterranean salinity crisis, and more recent colonisations and
   cladogenetic events during the Pleistocene climatic changes in the
   mountains of Greece.
C1 Casale, A.; Univ Sassari, Dipartimento Sci Nat & Terr, Via Muroni 25,
   Sassari, I-07100, Italy, Italy.
EM a_casale@libero.it
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0373-3491
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Subterranean habitat; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Duvalius (Duvalius) ionicus; Epiroella acharnanis; Speluncarius vailatii
   [Greece /  / New species]. 
   Invertebrata [Cave habitat /  / Faunal list] [Greece / Oros Serekas
   Mountain, Megalo Spilio / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea, Leiodidae
OR Invertebrata (Animalia). 
   Duvalius (Duvalius) ionicus (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 11]. 
   Speluncarius vailatii - Casale & Giachino 2013 (Carabidae): [Sp nov,
   Greece, P. 15]. 
   Epiroella acharnanis (Leiodidae): [Sp nov, Greece, P. 17].

TI The identification of the species and subspecies of the genus Tmethis
   Fieber 1853 in Maghreb (Caelifera, Pamphagidae, Thrinchinae).
FT Essai sur la determination des especes et sous-especes du genre Tmethis
   Fieber 1853 au Maghreb (Caelifera, Pamphagidae, Thrinchinae).
AU Defaut, Bernard (bdefaut@club-internet.fr) 
   Francois, Alexandre
SO Bulletin de l'Institut Scientifique Section Sciences de la Vie - Rabat
VL 35
PS 95-102
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The subspecies Tmethis maroccanus Bolivar ssp. hirtus Uvarov is assigned
   to the species T. cisti (F.) : Tmethis cisti (F.) ssp. hirtus Uvarov,
   comb.nov. We propose an identification key of the Tmethis of North
   Africa based on the criteria given by Uvarov (1943). We also present a
   distribution map of known taxa in the Maghreb; it shows a clear
   parapatry for at least three taxa (T. c. hirtus, T. c. cisti and T. c.
   clavelii), which poses the problem of their real taxonomic status.

TI [The Coccophagus (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae) of Guadeloupe.]
FT Les Coccophagus (Hymenoptera, Aphelinidae) de Guadeloupe.
AU Panis, Andre (a-panis@orange.fr)

VL 69

PS 37-43
PD 2013

LA French

AB The genus Coccophagus is reported for the first time in Guadeloupe, with
   three species : Coccophagus basalis COMPERE, Coccophagus pulvinariae
   COMPERE, Coccophagus sp. affin pulvinariae COMPERE, endoparasitoids of
   scale-insects of Coccidae family. Their morphological features are
   detailed, in particular for C. sp. affin pulvinariae, specific name of
   which would need to compare it to the descriptions of Neotropical
   Coccophagus. Its morphological features are translated in English.

VL 69

PS 44-46

LA French

U2 0
AB For the first time, we describe a new kind for the subfamily
   Tricycleinae LEHRER, 1970 of Romania : Dobrogiella n. gen. This one with
   its species-type Dobrogiella phallogreciana n. sp. are the first
   palearctic taxa, which have the male cerques forked and the phallosome
   of a type of different structure from that of the species of Tricylea
   WULP.

TI Two new Trechus species from Tunisia (Coleoptera Carabidae Trechini) and
   discussion about the fulvus species-complex in North-Africa.
FT Deux nouveaux Trechus de Tunisie (Coleoptera Carabidae Trechini) et
   discussion sur le complexe fulvus en Afrique du Nord.
AU Queinnec, Eric (eric.queinnec@upmc.fr) 
   Ollivier, Eric
SO Bulletin Mensuel de la Societe Linneenne de Lyon
VL 82
IS 1-2
PS 33-45
PD Jan 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB As part of an inventory of Carabidae from Tunisia many field surveys
   were conducted specifically targeting endogean and hypogean
   environments. This work led to the discovery of two new endemic Trechus
   species belonging to the species-complex of Trechus fulvus Dejean, 1831.
   Characters of these species are related to the group of Trechus
   lallemantii Fairmaire, 1859 that we redefine on the basis of a set of
   morphological characters.

DT Article
TI REVISION OF THE NEW WORLD SPECIES OF OEDICHIRUS (COLEOPTERA:
   STAPHYLINIDAE: PAEDERINAE: PINOPHILINI: PROCIRRINA).
AU Herman, Lee H.
SO Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History
VL 375
PS 1-137
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The New World species of Oedichirus Erichson, 1839, are revised,
   redescribed, or newly described, illustrated, and included in keys for
   identification. The morphology of the ventral pterothoracic sclerites is
   examined and Matsuda's (1970) interpretation is largely adopted over
   that of Ferris (1940b). Newly discovered characters of the median
   gonocoxal plate and associated vulvar plate, including its
   microstructures, are discussed. Prior to the present paper New World
   species were known in Brazil and Costa Rica, but are herein newly
   reported for the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, and
   Argentina; a specimen intercepted at a port in the United States was
   said to have come from Nicaragua. Eight species were previously
   described; 19 new ones are added herein, 12 from Brazil (0. apiculus, 0.
   batillus, 0. bicristatus, O.. bullaglaber, 0. bullahirtus, 0.
   clavolateralis, 0. clavuhis, 0. echinatus, 0. exilis, 0. glabrihamus, 0.
   lunatus, and 0. procerus), two from Mexico (0. isthmus and 0. sinuosus),
   and one each from Argentina (0. misionesiensis), Bolivia (0. dilophus),
   Ecuador (0. distortus), Peru (a hamatus), and Dominican Republic (0.
   dominicanensis). A neotype is designated for 0. geniculatus and
   lectotypes are designated for 0. brunneus Wendeler, 0. pictipes Bierig,
   0. ohausi Wendeler, 0. optatus Sharp, 0. sparsipennis Bernhauer, and 0.
   speculifrons Bernhauer. Some species are included in species groups.
C1 Herman, Lee H.; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Div Invertebrate Zool, New York,
   NY, 10024, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 0003-0090

   America; West Indies; South America

TI FAUNA AND FLORA OF HAWRAMAN MOUNTAIN (Part one) HAWRAMAN LOWEST ZONE,
   KURDISTAN PROVINCE NORTH EAST OF IRAQ.
AU Lahony, Saman R. Afrasiab
   Mohammad, Mohammad K.
   Ali, Hasan H.
   Al-Moussawi, Azhar A.
   Abd Al-Rasul, Mohammad S.
SO Bulletin of the Iraq Natural History Museum
VL 12
IS 4
PS 7-34
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study we try to make a first step for making a new list for
   fauna and flora of Kurdistan in particular and Iraq in general. This is
   very important study of biodiversity of Iraq. We recognize 52 migratory
   and resident birds including Alectoris chukar asoica which is recently
   described. Also, 20 amphibians and reptiles including two snakes
   recently recorded Zamenis hohenackeri and Platyceps ladacesis, a new
   form of Asaccus sp. and sub- species of Varanuns griseus caspeius for
   the first time in Iraq, with many rare specimens. Thirteen different
   species of mammals were recognized, with comments on 5 species of
   freshwater fishes, 12 species of ticks and 7 species of butterflies. For
   the flora, 8 wild large trees and 70 flowering plants identified
   including some rare and important species for the first time in this
   area. Figures are also given for the rare species.

DT Article
TI A new age finding in the Central Sakarya Region (NW Turkey).
AU Uguz, Mehmet Fuat (uguzmf@hotmail.com) 
SO Bulletin of the Mineral Research and Exploration
VL 146
PS 1-25
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The existence of a metamorphic basement cut by granitoids is known in
   the Central Sakarya region of northwest Turkey according to the previous
   studies. Over this metamorphic basement, there is a Liassic unit which
   contains ammonite, brachiopod and some benthic foraminifers and has a
   sequence starting with fluvial deposits at the base and grading into
   coastal, subtidal and shallow marine sediment character towards the top
   in the vicinity of Saricakaya district, Eskisehir City. At different
   levels of this unit which is called as the "Kapikaya Formation", the
   Campanian age fossils such as; Ceratolithoides aculeus (Stradner),
   Pervilithus varius Crux, Watznaueria barnesae (Black), Tortolithus sp.,
   Biscutum sp. Quadrum sissinghii Perch-Nielsen, Watznaueria barnesea
   Black, Ellipsagelosphaera fosscincta were identified in this study.
   These fossil findings clearly reveal the presence of a Campanian aged
   unit in the region. This unit is composed of flyschoidal facies deposits
   and includes exotic limestone blocks of Liassic age and is overlain by
   Malm [long dash] Early Cretaceous limestones at the same time. The
   overlying of Malm [long dash] Early Cretaceous rocks to Campanian
   deposits is closely related to the tectonics that has been effective in
   the region during or post Campanian.
C1 Uguz, Mehmet Fuat; General Directorate of Mineral Research and
   Exploration, Geological Researches Department, Ankara, Turkey, Turkey.
EM uguzmf@hotmail.com
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0026-4563
BD Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonoidea; Brachiopoda; Foraminiferida [Fossil assemblages /  / ]
   [Turkey / Central Sakarya Region / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Cretaceous / Campanian / ] [Jurassic / Liassic / ]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates; Molluscs; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina,
   Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea

TI Descriptions of two new families, three new species and re-description
   of four known genera and one subfamily from the larger benthic
   Foraminifera of Paleocene in Turkey.
AU Sirel, Ercument (sirel@ankara.edu.tr) 
SO Bulletin of the Mineral Research and Exploration
VL 146
PS 27-53
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new foraminiferal families are introduced as follows: the
   Anatoliellidae (type genus Anatoliella Sirel) in the superfamily
   Ataxophragmiacea Schwager and the family Bolkarinidae (type genus
   Bolkarina Sirel) in the superfamily Orbitoidacea Schwager. Three new
   species of Paleocene are described and figured as follows: Ranikothalia
   polatliensis, Nurdanella paleocenica, Periloculina yilmazi. In addition,
   four known Paleocene genera such as Bolkarina Sirel, Globoflarina
   Rahaghi, Nurdanella Ozgen and Coskinon Hottinger and Drobne and
   subfamily Globoflarininae are redescribed.

DT Article
TI Paraconularia bachmanni n. sp. from the Germanic Upper Triassic, the
   first fresh-water occurrence of a conulariid.
AU Barth, Gregor (gregor.barth@geopal.de) 
   Kozur, Heinz W.
   Franz, Matthias
   Weems, Robert E.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 42-47
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB For the first time a conulariid fossil, Paraconularia bachmanni n. sp.,
   has been found in the Germanic Upper Triassic. All previously known
   conulariids were fully marine, but Paraconularia bachmanni n. sp. was
   found in a fresh water lake deposit. The presence of a specimen of this
   normally marine fossil group in a fresh water lake deposit suggests that
   this species was a euryhaline marine conulariid that normally lived in a
   nearby large brackish sea but occasionally penetrated into fresh water
   areas far from the marine realm.
C1 Barth, Gregor; Technische Universitaet Bergakademie Freiberg, Institut
   fuer Geologie, Bernhard-von-Cotta-Str. 2, 09599 Freiberg, Germany,
   Germany.
EM gregor.barth@geopal.de
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology; Zoology;
   Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Conulariida [Freshwater habitat /  / New record] [Germany /  / ]
   [Triassic / Upper Triassic / ]. 
   Paraconularia bachmanni [Germany /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ].

ST Animalia, Conulariida
OR Conulariida (Animalia): [Fossil; New record].

   45; Fossil].

DT Article
TI LATE SMITHIAN (EARLY TRIASSIC) CONODONTS FROM ARTYOM, SOUTH PRIMORYE,
   RUSSIAN FAR EAST.
AU Bondarenko, Liana G. (li_bond@mail.ru) 
   Buryi, Galina I.
   Zakharov, Yuri D.
   Bushkareva, Xenia Y.
   Popov, Alexander M.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 55-66
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Late Smithian (Olenekian) Anasibirites nevolini Zone yields abundant
   conodonts in the SMID Quarry section at Artyom, South Primorye, Russian
   Far East. Twenty species are described: Discritella dicreta (Muller),
   Ellisonia nevadensis Muller, Ellisonia triassica Muller, Furnishius
   triserratus Clark, Hadrodontina sp., Neospathodus ex gr. waageni Sweet,
   N. novaehollandiae McTavish, Scythogondolella milleri (Muller), S.
   mosheri (Kozur and Mostler) and S. sp., including neogondolellid
   elements. The Olenekian (late Smithian) Scythogondolella milleri Zone
   represents the 18 m thick lower member A of the Anasibirites nevolini
   Zone. Member A yields at its base: Neospathodus ex gr. waageni Sweet,
   Ellisonia nevadensis Muller, E. triassica Muller, Furnishius triserratus
   Clark, Scythogondolella milleri (Muller) and S. mosheri (Kozur and
   Mostler), with S. milleri (Muller) occurring also at the top and
   neogondolellid P2, S3-4/S0 Group B elements. Furnishius triserratus
   Clark, and Ellisonia triassica Muller also occur at the top of the 10 m
   thick member B, "Hindeodella" Group B Beds with Neospathodus
   novaehollandiae McTavish, Discretella discreta (Muller), Hadrodontina
   sp., and Neogondolellid S3-4/S0 Group A, B elements.
C1 Bondarenko, Liana G.; Far East Geological Institute, Far Eastern Branch,
   Russian Academy of Sciences, Stoletiya prospect 159, Vladivostok,
   690022, Russia, Russia.
EM li_bond@mail.ru

DT Article
TI INTERCALIBRATION OF CONODONT AND RADIOLARIAN FAUNAS FROM THE
   CARNIAN-NORIAN BOUNDARY INTERVAL IN HAIDA GWAII, BRITISH COLUMBIA,
   CANADA.
AU Carter, Elizabeth S. (cartermicro@earthlink.net) 
   Orchard, Michael J.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 67-92
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Forty-four radiolarian faunules from the Carnian-Norian Boundary (CNB)
   beds of the Peril Formation at 11 localities in Haida Gwaii are grouped
   into 7 radiolarian assemblages that are independently dated by conodonts
   and macrofossils. The age and stratigraphic distribution of 140
   radiolarian species are determined by reference to the conodont zonation
   introduced at the GSSP candidate section at Black Bear Ridge in
   northeast British Columbia (Orchard, this volume). This zonation, based
   on successions within the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin, is thereby
   shown to be broadly applicable in Wrangellia, an accreted terrane with
   Tethyan affinities. Beyond demonstrating the utility of the conodont
   zonation, a parallel radiolarian zonation for the CNB is developed for
   the oceanic realm. The oldest radiolarian faunas in Haida Gwaii
   constitute Assemblage 1, which occurs throughout the islands, and is
   associated with upper Carnian ammonoids of the upper Welleri Zone, and
   contains 55 widely recognized taxa. Significant radiolarian faunal
   change begins with the first appearance of 14 well-known species in
   Assemblage 2c, which corresponds to the Upper samueli Subzone and n. sp.
   Q. Zone. The greatest number of new species, 31, are added with
   Assemblage 3, coincident with the equally diverse radiation of conodonts
   assigned to the "Lower primitia Zone." A conodont turnover within the
   overlying parvus Zone, favored as a datum for the CNB, is reflected in
   the addition of 16 species in Assemblage 4. Above this zone, a further
   14 species appear in Assemblage 5, the "Upper primitia Zone." Together
   these 75 species define radiolarian change from latest Carnian to early
   Norian in Haida Gwaii. One new species, Deflandrecyrtium burnabyense, is
   described. This study finds that some taxa previously believed to have
   their last appearance in the late Carnian actually range into the early
   Norian, and conversely that others known mostly from the early Norian
   are present in late Carnian assemblages. This applies to sample A9a from
   the GSSP candidate section at Pizzo Mondello, Sicily where virtually all
   elements of the radiolarian fauna regarded as evidence for an early
   Norian age occur in the late to latest Carnian of Haida Gwaii.
C1 Carter, Elizabeth S.; 69745 Old Wagon Road, Sisters, OR 97759, USA, USA.
EM cartermicro@earthlink.net
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156

   region; North America; Canada; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

DT Article
TI A COMPREHENSIVE SURVEY OF TRIASSIC STEREOSPONDYLS FROM SOUTHERN BRAZIL
   WITH COMMENTS ON THEIR OVERALL SIGNIFICANCE.
AU Dias-da-Silva, Sergio (sergiosilva@unipampa.edu.br) 
   Dias, Eliseu Vieira
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 93-103
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fossil record of Triassic stereospondyls from southern Brazil has
   expanded significantly in the last 27 years, increasing their overall
   significance among fossil assemblages from the Rosario do Sul Group
   (Triassic of Parana Basin). They are quite abundant in Lower Triassic
   strata (Sanga do Cabral Formation), comprising presumed lydekkerinids,
   undoubted rhytidosteids (Sangaia lavinai), mastodonsauroids,
   plagiosaurine plagiosaurids, and unnumbered dermal fragments attributed
   to Stereospondyli indet. So far, they are not represented in the Middle
   Triassic (Ladinian of the Santa Maria Formation), probably due to either
   insufficient prospecting or taphonomic biases. Upper Triassic
   occurrences (Carnian of the Santa Maria Formation) include very large
   fragmentary remains of uncertain affinities and a juvenile
   chigutisaurid, regarded as a second specimen of the Indian genus
   Compsocerops. A single postcranial element (an interclavicle) of a
   putative mastodonsauroid was recovered from the Caturrita Formation
   (Norian). The record of this group in the South Brazilian Triassic
   clearly shows that they were much more diverse and abundant in this part
   of Gondwana than previously noted. Additionally, they serve as tools for
   biostratigraphic correlation as well as palaeobiogeographic
   interpretations, especially when taking into consideration diagnostic
   Lower Triassic specimens and Compsocerops sp.

   Gabriel, Rio Grande do Sul, CEP 97.300-000, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI THE MARINE PACHYPLEUROSAUR SERPIANOSAURUS GERMANICUS NOV. SPEC. -
   SKELETON AND ISOLATED BONE REMAINS FROM THE PELSONIAN (MIDDLE TRIASSIC)
   OF THE EUROPEAN GERMANIC BASIN CARBONATE INTERTIDALS AND ITS
   PALEOBIOLOGY AND TAPHONOMY.
AU Diedrich, Cajus G. (cdiedri@gmx.net) 
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 159-168
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The large marine pachypleurosaur sauropterygian Serpianosaurus
   germanicus nov. spec., representing the oldest well known record of this
   genus from the Pelsonian, is introduced based on a postcranial skeleton.
   Of younger age are the Serpianosaurus mirigolensis (Rieppel, 1989)
   specimens from the Illyrian/Fassanian boundary (Grenzbitumen Bed) of the
   northwestern Tethys (Monte San Giorgio). Additional materials from
   Germany contain individual remains of different sexes and ages, all of
   which have been found in shallow marine to intertidal carbonate
   deposits. The postcranial skeleton and single bone remains from the
   Karlstadt Formation (upper Pelsonian, Anisian) of the Middle Triassic
   from different German sites demonstrate that this genus is more common
   in the Germanic Basin, but also is present in the northern Tethys. The
   paleogeography and facies distribution indicate evaporative to shallow
   marine conditions with extensive intertidal flats and sabkhas on the
   southern Germanic Basin coasts at that time. One possible reason for the
   abundance of Serpianosaurus during late Pelsonian time is a food chain
   that was based on horseshoe crabs, the eggs of which might have been a
   main target for the fish that were the primary food source for the
   pachypleurosaurs. Serpianosaurus and other marine vertebrates may have
   been killed by storm events and their carcasses deposited on intertidal
   flats where they were themselves food sources for large carnivorous
   thecodont archosaurs such as Ticinosuchus (Chirotherium tracks), or
   ?Arizonasaurus (Isochirotherium tracks), the footprints of which occur
   on the intertidals where Serpianosaurus and other marine vertebrate
   remains were deposited.
C1 Diedrich, Cajus G.; PaleoLogic, Research Institute, Nansenstrasse 8,
   D-33790 Halle/Westphalia, Germany, Germany.
EM cdiedri@gmx.net

TI TRIASSIC VERTEBRATE COPROLITE ICHNOFAUNAS.
AU Hunt, Adrian P. (adrianhu@flyingheritage.com) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
   Spielmann, Justin A.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 237-258
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB There is an abundant record of vertebrate coprolites in the Triassic.
   The Early Triassic record is quite limited and occurs only in Europe,
   Australia and South Africa. The distribution of coprolites in the Middle
   Triassic is worldwide, with occurrences in the USA, South Africa,
   Russia, Kazakhstan, Argentina, Brazil, India, Poland, Slovenia, Germany,
   England, France, Switzerland, Italy and China. The Late Triassic sample
   size is the largest, with records in the USA, Greenland, England,
   Netherlands, Switzerland, Germany, Madagascar, India, Brazil, Morocco
   and South Africa. The majority of Late Triassic coprolites are from the
   Chinle Group and Newark Supergroup in North America and the Rhaetic
   bonebeds in Europe. Santamariacopros elongatus ichnogen et ichnosp. nov.
   and Rhynchocopros soutoi ichnogen et ichnosp. are new ichnotaxa of
   coprolites of herbivores from the Middle Triassic Santa Maria Formation
   of Brazil.

   WA 98204, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI STRATIGRAPHICALLY IMPORTANT LOWER NORIAN CONODONTS FROM THE CSOVAR
   BOREHOLE (CSV-1), HUNGARY - COMPARISON WITH THE CONODONT SUCCESSION OF
   THE NORIAN GSSP CANDIDATE PIZZO MONDELLO (SICILY, ITALY).
AU Karadi, Viktor (kavik.geo@gmail.com) 
   Kozur, Heinz W.
   Gorog, Agnes
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 284-295
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We investigated the lower part (360-522 m) of the cherty limestones of
   the Csovar Limestone Formation in the Csovar borehole (Csv-1) for
   conodonts. The interval below 404 m was assigned to the upper Carnian by
   Goczan in Haas et al. (1997); our conodont studies indicate that this
   level lies in the upper Epigondolella triangularis Zone within the upper
   part of the lower Norian. The Carnian-Norian boundary instead lies near
   the base of the cherty limestones at 522 m. The lowermost 6 m of the
   cherty limestones have yielded only a few conodonts at 520 m. These are
   only early juvenile Epigondolella that cannot be exactly assigned to a
   species, but probably the age does not differ from the conodonts at 516
   m, where primitive Epigondolella quadrata Orchard, E. rigoi Kozur and
   Metapolygnathus mazzai Karadi, Kozur and Gorog n. sp. occur that can be
   assigned to the lowermost Norian. Thus, the Norian base lies more than
   112 m (and probably 116 m) below the Norian base assumed in Haas et al.
   (1997). The position of the Carnian-Norian boundary is discussed in
   detail. In the GSSP candidate sections at Pizzo Mondello (Sicily, Italy)
   and Black Bear Ridge, British Columbia, Canada, this boundary interval
   lies between the youngest Carnian and the oldest Norian ammonoids. The
   best primary markers for the Norian base are conodonts and Halobia
   austriaca (Mojsisovics). Conodonts are preferred as primary marker for
   the Norian base. The most suitable is the FAD of Epigondolella rigoi in
   the middle of the Carnian-Norian boundary interval. It nearly coincides
   with the LOD of Metapolygnathus echinatus sensu Orchard (2007). Good
   proxies for the base of the Norian are the FAD of Metapolygnathus parvus
   Kozur, M. echinatus sensu Orchard (2007), the LOD of M. echinatus sensu
   Orchard (2007), the FAD of Carnepigondolella gulloae Mazza and Rigo, and
   the LOD of Metapolygnathus communisti Hayashi and of M. parvus. Also,
   the general change of a Carnepigondolella (and Metapolygnathus)
   dominated conodont fauna with few primitive Epigondolella to a
   Epigondolella (and Norigondolella) dominated fauna with few remaining
   Metapolygnathus and Carnepigondolella is good evidence for the position
   of the Carnian-Norian boundary. We describe two new species,
   Metapolygnathus mazzai Karadi, Kozur and Gorog n. sp. and Oncodella
   mostleri Karadi, Kozur and Gorog n. sp.
C1 Karadi, Viktor; Pazmany Peter setany 1/c, Eotvos Lorand University,
   Faculty of Science, Department Palaeontology, H-1117 Budapest, Hungary,
   Hungary.
EM kavik.geo@gmail.com
RI Gorog, Agnes/K-9996-2018
OI Gorog, Agnes/0000-0002-0910-8822

TI SHIPINGIA WEEMSI N. SP., A BIOSTRATIGRAPHICALLY IMPORTANT CONCHOSTRACAN
   SPECIES FROM THE UPPERMOST CARNIAN AND LOWERMOST NORIAN OF CENTRAL
   EUROPE.
AU Kozur, Heinz W. (kozurh@helka.iif.hu) 
   Franz, Matthias
   Bachmann, Gerhard H.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 325-330
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The index species of the basal Norian monospecific "Palaeolimnadia
   schwanbergensis Zone" does not belong to that genus or species. Instead,
   it is a primitive Shipingia species (transitional to Palaeolimnadia)
   here named Shipingia weemsi n. sp. The type specimen of Palaeolimnadia
   schwanbergensis Reible comes from the "Berggipsschichten" of Iphofen of
   early Tuvalian age. It is a distinctly different species closely related
   to an undescribed Palaeolimnadia of the upper Schilfsandstein.
   Therefore, the uppermost Tuvalian Laxitextella freybergi-
   "Palaeolimnadia schwanbergensis" Zone and the basal Norian monospecific
   "Palaeolimnadia schwanbergensis" Zone of Kozur and Weems (2010) must be
   re-named the Laxitextella freybergi-Shipingia weemsi Zone and the
   Shipingia weemsi Zone, respectively. In the central basin facies of the
   Germanic Basin, the Laxitextella freybergiShipingia weemsi Zone occurs
   in the uppermost Heldburg Gypsum Member of the Weser Formation
   (uppermost Tuvalian) and the S. weemsi Zone occurs in the basal
   Arnstadt-Formation (basal Norian). The occurrence of S. weemsi on both
   sides of the Heldburg Gypsum Member of the Weser Formation-Arnstadt
   Formation lithostratigraphic boundary, as well as the gradual change of
   the conchostracan faunas from the late Tuvalian Coburg Sandstone
   (Laxitextella freybergi Zone) through the latest Tuvalian Heldburg
   Gypsum Member (Laxitextella freybergi-Shipingia weemsi Zone) to the
   basal Lacian Arnstadt Formation (Shipingia weemsi Zone), indicates that
   there is not a long time-gap within the central basin facies at the
   "Early Cimmerian Unconformity" ("Altkimmerische Hauptdiskordanz").

TI EVAZOUM GATEWAYENSIS, A NEW LATE TRIASSIC ARCHOSAURIAN ICHNOSPECIES FROM
   COLORADO: IMPLICATIONS FOR FOOTPRINTS IN THE ICHNOFAMILY OTOZOIDAE.
AU Lockley, Martin G. (martin.lockley@UCDenver.edu) 
   Lucas, Spencer G.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 345-353
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Evazoum gatewayensis is a new ichnospecies named for distinctive forms
   of Evazoum from the Upper Triassic Chinle Group of western Colorado that
   are up to twice the size of the type species of Evazoum, an ichnogenus
   that has been compared with Kalosauropus, and assigned to the Otozoum,
   Pseudotetrasauropus, Evazoum, Kalosauropus or OPEK plexus. E.
   gatewayensis tracks are functionally didactyl, with an enlarged proximal
   metatarsal-phalangeal pad on digit II, separated by a conspicuous gap
   from a distal digit II claw trace. This enlarged pad and gap is lacking
   in other Evazoum and OPEK morphotypes, which also show the trace of
   digit I in most specimens. Thus, the western Colorado tracks suggest
   that the trackmaker retracted its digit II claw, as well as keeping
   digit I above the substrate. This could indicate both a morphological
   and behavioral difference between this ichnospecies and others in the
   OPEK plexus. The western Colorado morphotypes, which also appear to be
   represented by specimens in eastern Utah, and similar footprints from
   Nova Scotia, show interesting convergence with the tracks of Cretaceous
   deinonychosaurs, although we infer that the track makers belonged to a
   different group of archosaurs. Based on current trackway evidence,
   Evazoum is a variable ichnogenus in size, morphology, and behavior, and
   like several ichnogenera in the OPEK plexus, is currently represented by
   more than one ichnospecies.
C1 Lockley, Martin G.; Dinosaur Tracks Museum, University of Colorado
   Denver, PO Box 173364, Denver, CO 80217, USA, USA.
EM martin.lockley@UCDenver.edu

SN 1524-4156

   Newly described trace fossil, Triassic, Colorado / ] [Colorado /  /
   newly described trace fossil] [Triassic /  / ] [ / Late Triassic /
   Footprints Otozoidae]. 
   Evazoum gatewayensis [Fossil tracks / New species possibly attributable
   to Archosauria (Reptilia), Triassic, Colorado / ] [Colorado /  / new
   species; Described from fossil track; possibly attributable to
   Archosauria (Reptilia)] [Triassic /  / ].

   (Reptilia); Fossil].

DT Article
TI A NEW DOSWELLIID ARCHOSAUROMORPH FROM THE UPPER TRIASSIC OF WEST TEXAS.
AU Lucas, Spencer G. (spencer.lucas@state.nm.us) 
   Spielmann, Justin A.
   Hunt, Adrian P.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 382-388
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ankylosuchus chinlegroupensis is a new genus and species of
   heavily-armored archosauromorph from the Otischalkian Colorado City
   Formation of the Chinle Group in Howard County, West Texas. The
   incomplete holotype skeleton consists of cranial and pelvic (?)
   elements, vertebral centra, a partial limb shaft and numerous
   osteoderms. The skull elements reveal a thick, heavily armored braincase
   and skull roof with parasagittal crests. The relatively short sacral
   vertebrae suggest an animal less than 1 meter in total body length, not
   including the tail. The morphology of the osteoderms does not match any
   currently known armored archosauromorph, but it is most similar to
   doswelliids. Most of the osteoderms possess large, closely packed pits
   that form no obvious pattern. Some osteoderms have raised, linear ridges
   running across them and others have anterior laminae with faint
   patterning on the articular surface. Some of the osteoderms are tightly
   sutured to each other via digitate sutures; all are relatively thick.
   The patterning of the ostoderms matches well with that of doswellids in
   being coarse, deeply incised and mostly composed of equal-sized pits and
   in the possession of anterior laminae. Even so, these osteoderms are
   readily distinguished from those of Doswellia, the only doswelliid
   previously reported from the Chinle Group, by their coarser pitting,
   greater thickness and (at least in some osteoderms) fusion with
   laterally adjacent osteoderms along their mutual sutural boundaries. A.
   chinlegroupensis is derived from the oldest strata of the Texas Chinle
   Group, the Otischalkian, whereas the genus Doswellia is known from the
   Chinle Group in Texas, New Mexico and Utah, in strata of
   Otischalkian-Adamanian (late Carnian) age. Doswelliids are very rare,
   but visible components of global Triassic faunas. They include Tarjadia
   (= Archeopelta) from the Berdyankian (Ladinian) of Argentina and Brazil,
   Doswellia from the Otischalkian-Adamanian of the American Southwest and
   the Otischalkian of the Newark Supergroup in the eastern USA, and now
   Ankylosuchus from the Otischalkian of West Texas.
C1 Lucas, Spencer G.; New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science,
   1801 Mountain Rd. NW, Albuquerque, NM 87104-1375, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI FIVE NEW GENERA OF CONODONTS FROM THE CARNIAN-NORIAN BOUNDARYBEDS OF
   BLACK BEAR RIDGE, NORTHEAST BRITISH COLUMBIA, CANADA.
AU Orchard, Michael J. (morchard@nrcan.gc.ca) 
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 445-457
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A high-level taxonomic revision of conodonts from the Carnian-Norian
   boundary (CNB) interval in the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin is
   provided as a prelude to a monographic report. Five new genera -
   Acuminatella, Kraussodontus, Parapetella, Primatella, and Quadralella -
   are introduced, four of which are represented by newly described type
   species: Acuminatella acuminata, Kraussodontus peteri, Parapetella
   prominens, and Quadralella lobata. In addition, Acuminatella angusta,
   Carnepigondolella eozoae, C. medioconstricta, Primatella asymmetrica,
   and P. conservativa are newly described. Amended diagnoses are provided
   for the genera Carnepigondolella, Epigondolella, Metapolygnathus, and
   Paragondolella. Based on both new and established species, and many
   others as yet undescribed, the CNB interval spanning the Welleri (part),
   Macrolobatus and Kerri ammonoid zones is informally divided into eight
   conodont zones and subzones, plus a further three intervals that can be
   potentially delineated near the top of three of these zones. The main
   zones are the Lower, Middle, and Upper samueli subzones, n. sp. Q Zone,
   "Lower primitia Zone," parvus Zone, "Upper primitia Zone," and quadrata
   Zone.
C1 Orchard, Michael J.; Natural Resources Canada-Geological Survey of
   Canada, 1500-605 Robson St., Vancouver, BC, V6B 5J3, Canada, Canada.
EM morchard@nrcan.gc.ca

DT Article
TI MIDDLE TRIASSIC VERTEBRATE REMAINS FROM RASA VILLAGE (VARESE, NORTHERN
   ITALY).
AU Renesto, Silvio (silvio.renesto@uninsubria.it) 
   Pieroni, Vittorio
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 485-488
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two isolated teeth from the Dolomia del San Salvatore (S. Salvatore
   Dolomite) and an isolated humerus from the Cunardo Formation, both
   Middle Triassic in age, are described. The two teeth are attributed to
   ?Ticinosuchus sp. and to ?Helveticosaurus sp. respectively, and the
   humerus to Neusticosaurus cf. N. pusillus. These discoveries are of
   interest because the teeth belong to taxa known from few specimens and
   represent the first undisputed vertebrate fossils collected from the San
   Salvatore Dolomite. The Neusticosaurus humerus is also noteworthy
   because it is only the second reptile specimen collected from the
   Cunardo Formation.
C1 Renesto, Silvio; Department of Theoretical and Applied Sciences,
   Universita degli Studi dell'Insubria, via Dunant 3, I-21100 Varese,
   Italy, Italy.
EM silvio.renesto@uninsubria.it

DT Article
TI CONODONT BIOSTRATIGRAPHY OF PERMIAN-TRIASSIC BOUNDARY DEPOSITS IN
   KOH-E-CHAH KALAND, NORTH OF ABADEH, IRAN.
AU Shooshtarizadeh, Peyman (p_shooshtarizadeh@yahoo.com) 
   Yazdi, Mehdi
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 543-555
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 2
U2 2
AB The Koh-e chah kaland section is located 35 km north of Abadeh; 103
   meters of this Upper Permian to Lower Triassic section were studied.
   This section consists of three lithologic units: the Upper Permian Unit
   6 consisting of medium-bedded dolomitic limestone, the Upper Permian
   Unit 7 consisting of thin-bedded limestone, and the Lower Triassic unit,
   a gray, thin-bedded limestone. Systematic sampling and study on its
   conodonts led to the identification of 9 genera, 22 species and 9
   conodont biozones: the lower Dzhulfian Clarkina leveni Zone of Unit 6,
   the Upper Dzhufian Clarkina transcaucasica Zone, Clarkina orientalis
   Zone and Clarkina longicuspidata Zone, the basal Changhsingian Clarkina
   hambastensis zone, the Clarkina bachmanni Zone (lower part of upper
   Changsingian), the upper Changhsingian Clarkina changxigensis Zone (all
   Unit 7), the Gangetian Hindeodus parvus Zone and Isarcicella isarcica
   Zone (Unit a). The Permian-Triassic boundary is characterized by the
   first appearance of Hindeodus parvus in sample K28. One of the Clarkina
   species is especially important because of its similarity to C.
   dukouensis, but younger than C. dukouensis. Also important is the first
   evidence of rare specimens of Clarkina abadehensis within the C.
   changxingensis-C. deflecta Zone, whereas in Iran and in Transcaucasia C.
   iranica begins only two conodont zones higher, in the C. iranica Zone.
   Therefore, C. iranica cannot be a synonym of C. abadehenis. Another
   important species is Mesogondolella n. sp., the successor of M.
   britannica Kozur, which characterizes the basal Zechstein of
   northwestern Europe. As Mesogondolella n. sp. occurs in the C.
   transcaucasica Zone, the base of the Zechstein must be older than the
   late Dzhulfian C. transcaucasica Zone.
C1 Shooshtarizadeh, Peyman; Islamic Azad University, Science and Research
   Branch, Tehran, Iran, Iran.
EM p_shooshtarizadeh@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic; Palaeozoic
DE Clarkina abadehensis; Hindeodus parvus [Iran / Abadeh, Koh-e-chah Kaland
   / new record] [Triassic / Permian Boundary / ] [Permian / Triassic
   Boundary / ]. 
   Conodonta [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Iran / Abadeh,
   Koh-e-chah Kaland / stratigraphical distribution] [Triassic / Permian

TI LATE SMITHIAN (EARLY TRIASSIC) AMMONOIDS FROM THE ANASIBIRITES NEVOLINI
   ZONE OF SOUTH PRIMORYE, RUSSIAN FAR EAST.
AU Zakharov, Yuri D. (yurizakh@mail.ru) 
   Bondarenko, Liana G.

SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 61
PS 597-612
PD 2013

LA English

AB One new ammonoid genus (Ussuriaspenites) of the family Aspenitidae and
   10 new ammonoid species (Ussuriaspenites evlanovi, Monneticeras
   kalinkini, Brayardites involutus, Anasibirites simanenkoi, Prionites
   subtuberculatus, P. markevichi, Anawasatchites specious, Kashmirites
   shevyrevi, Xenoceltites? subvariocostatus, and Mianwaliites zimini) are
   described. The Anasibirites nevolini Zone corresponds to late Smithian
   sequences of the Central Himalayas and Salt Range such as the
   Wasatchites distractus, Subvishnuites posterus, and Glyptophiceras
   sinuatum beds.

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI A NEW SPECIES OF GLAPHYROPHLEBIA HANDLIRSCH, 1906 (INSECTA: NEOPTERA:
   BLATTINOPSIDAE) FROM THE LOWER PERMIAN WELLINGTON FORMATION OF NOBLE
   COUNTY, OKLAHOMA, USA.
AU Beckemeyer, Roy J. (royjbeckemeyer@cox.net) 
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 60
PS 7-11
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of the fossil insect genus Glaphyrophlebia are known from
   the Wellington Formation of Kansas (USA). In 1909, E. H. Sellards
   described G. ovata (Sellards, 1909) in the genus Pursa and G. speciosa
   (Sellards, 1909) in the genus Sindon. In 1966, Carpenter assigned both
   species to Glaphyrophlebia Handlirsch (1906a). Glaphyrophlebia
   anderhalterorum n. sp. is described from a specimen collected from the
   Wellington Formation in Noble County, Oklahoma. Most species of
   Glaphyrophlebia are known from fossil remains of forewings (often
   fragmentary), and occasionally hind wings. The holotype of G.
   amderhalterorum is a compression fossil comprising a nearly intact
   insect in dorsal aspect with articulated wings, and with portions of the
   hind, mid and fore-legs, thorax, and a portion of the head and abdomen
   preserved. This appears to be only the second glaphyrophlebiid fossil
   for which significant portions of body parts are preserved; a specimen
   of G. uralensis (Martynov, 1940) comprised a complete insect in lateral
   aspect, with body, head, legs, wings, and genitalia intact. G.
   anderhalterorum is the first species of Glaphyrophlebia to be described
   from the Oklahoma Permian.
C1 Beckemeyer, Roy J.; Division of Entomology (Paleoentomology), Natural
   History Museum, 1501 Crestline Drive - Suite 140, University of Kansas,
   Lawrence, Kansas 66045, USA, USA.
EM royjbeckemeyer@cox.net
SC Zoology
SN 1524-4156

   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic

   record] [Permian /  / ].

   / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

   Glaphyrophlebia anderhalterorum (Protorthoptera): [Sp nov, Oklahoma,
   Permian, P. 7; Fossil].
